subject: Re: [junit] RE: Testing Private Methods
msgSnippet: ... Another similar option is giving them package level access (no modifier) which will allow your unit tests in the same package (if you took this approach
messageBody:
> 4) Make the methods 'protected', have your Test class inherit from
> your class under test.
> This does work, however having a bunch of protected methods in your
> class interface could give the impression to future users that the
> class was designed to be inherited from, which is not really true in
> this case...

Another similar option is giving them 'package' level access (no
modifier) which will allow your unit tests in the same package (if you
took this approach to organizing them) to access the methds, but not
just any subclass. Only subclasses in the same package would have
access.

If you wanted to be *really* sure it wasn't subclassed, of course, you
can declare it final, but that certainly doesn't solve the general case
of your question.

Lastly, I wouldn't say that this suggestion is a particularly elegant
solution, and I could certainly be convinced that there's a better
approach.


$.02

Kevin
